title: NFL insider: Patriots ‘will be’ 1 of the teams interested in trading for Maxx Crosby
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots reportedly interested in trading for Raiders edge rusher Maxx Crosby, who recorded 10 sacks in 2025.
Crosby's relationship with the Raiders strained over a decision to shut him down due to a knee issue.
NFL insider Albert Breer suggests Patriots are contenders for Crosby, citing Mike Vrabel as a key draw.

title: Cyclists clear snow from Comm. Ave. bike lanes after storm, call on city for accountability
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Boston volunteers cleared snow from Commonwealth Avenue bike lanes after city delays, urging improved winter cycling safety.
The Boston Cyclists Union and BU Urbanism Club mobilized after numerous complaints about impassable bike lanes.
City officials removed 6,200 truckloads of snow, but complaints persist about inadequate bike lane clearing.

title: 7 things to do this Valentine’s Day weekend
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Boston Frostival at Copley Square offers winter-themed activities, including a Ferris Wheel ride, pizza-making, and arts and crafts.
Watch the new 'Wuthering Heights' adaptation starring Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi, opening on Friday, Feb. 13.
Try new Asian restaurants in Boston, including Novo Lantern, Boxfish, and K-Bok, with a Lunar New Year festival on Feb. 15.

title: City’s police oversight agency is finally starting to subpoena Boston cops
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Boston's Office of Police Accountability and Transparency has subpoenaed nine officers amid non-cooperation with oversight inquiries.
This marks the first use of OPAT's subpoena power, established by a 2021 ordinance to enforce transparency and accountability.
Failure of officers to appear could lead to contempt proceedings, emphasizing ongoing tension with the Boston Police Department.

title: Third wheels are the best wheels
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Meredith Goldstein explores the positive aspects of 'third wheeling' in her Love Letters column.
Research suggests couples may avoid inviting singles due to 'cocooning', neglecting single friendships.
Experts believe involving single friends could benefit couples, enhancing social dynamics and friendships.

title: How losing their parents led two brothers to the Boston Marathon
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Brothers Connor and Collin Nally are running the 2026 Boston Marathon for Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, aiming to raise $27,000.
The brothers were motivated by personal loss, having lost both parents and a fiancée's mother to cancer.
This is Collin's second marathon and Connor's first, running to honor their late parents and support cancer families.

title: After stage 3 blood cancer, Lynnfield woman will return for 7th Boston Marathon
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Allison Milford from Lynnfield will run her 7th Boston Marathon in 2026 to support the Boston Athletic Association.
Diagnosed with stage 3 blood cancer in her 20s, Milford completed her first Boston Marathon in 2011 after recovery.
Milford has completed 26 marathons and is raising funds to help at-risk children access healthy lifestyle programs.

title: DHS criticizes city councilor after chaotic ICE arrest in Roslindale
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: DHS criticized City Councilor Enrique Pepén for condemning an ICE operation in Roslindale involving Jose Perez-Antonio.
Pepén claimed ICE agents 'abducted' a neighbor during the operation, calling the incident 'scary and not right.'
DHS labeled Perez-Antonio a 'criminal illegal alien' while Pepén defended the Boston Trust Act limiting ICE cooperation.

title: Nice weather kicks off the holiday weekend, but will the next storm system be a hit or miss?
author: David Epstein
bullets: Sunny and mild conditions expected for the long holiday weekend in Massachusetts and Rhode Island.
Saturday and Sunday to feature temperatures in the upper 30s in Southern New England, 20s up north.
A coastal storm may affect the area on Monday, though it's likely to miss Southern New England.

title: What K’Lavon Chaisson and Jaylinn Hawkins said about upcoming free agency
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots' K’Lavon Chaisson and Jaylinn Hawkins are set to enter free agency next month.
Chaisson, a linebacker, had a breakout season with 7.5 sacks and hopes to re-sign with the Patriots.
Hawkins, who recorded four interceptions, expressed a strong desire to return to the Patriots.
